BC-JAPAN-URANIUM-BOS 
WORKER ERROR LEADS TO LETHAL RADIATION LEAK IN JAPAN 

   (For use by New York Times News Service clients)  
 By SHARON MOSHAVI  
 c.1999 The Boston Globe  
 

   TOKYO _ In what experts call the world's worst nuclear accident
since Chernobyl, dangerous levels of radiation leaked from a
uranium processing plant, creating an uncontrolled nuclear reaction
that exposed 19 people to radiation poisoning and forced the
evacuation of hundreds living near the factory.

   Hours after the leak, radiation levels immediately outside the
plant, in the town of Tokaimura, were as much as 10,000 times the
normal level, and 10 times the normal rate at a distance of 1 1/4
miles from the plant, according to government officials.

   This morning, officials said the nuclear chain reaction appeared
to have halted, but they were seeking confirmation from radiation
monitors at the plant, which processes uranium for nuclear fuel.

   An official at the Science and Technology Agency said that while
neutron levels appeared to have fallen, suggesting that the chain
reaction was over, it had yet to verify that this in fact had taken
place.

   Radiation specialists had been sent to the plant 70 miles
northeast of Tokyo, but more than 20 hours after the accident it
was still too dangerous for them to enter the facility. Rain began
to fall in the hours after the accident, prompting concerns that it
could spread the radiation.

   Government spokesman Hiromu Nonaka called the accident
``unprecedented,'' although it is much more localized and less
threatening than an accident at a nuclear-energy plant such as
Chernobyl.

   It is certain to raise concerns here about Japan's heavy
reliance on nuclear power, particularly since it has already faced
a series of mishaps at nuclear facilities in recent years.

   Experts say the reaction apparently occurring within the plant
could end any number of ways. It could, at some point, fizzle out
once it has used up its radioactive material. But there's also the
possibility that the reaction could lead to some sort of chemical
explosion.

   Japanese officials were slow to respond to the accident, and
initially played down its severity. At first, only 150 people
living within 350 yards of the plant were evacuated. Officials
later ordered 310,000 people living within a six-mile radius of the
plant to remain indoors with their windows closed, but these
warnings did not come until 12 hours after the accident was first
reported.

   Officials, though, may not have known until late in the
afternoon, hours after the accident, that a nuclear reaction was
taking place.

   Three workers are believed to have caused the accident on
Thursday morning when they were engaged in the delicate and
dangerous task of processing 35 pounds of uranium into fuel for
nuclear power plants, according to Makata Ujihara, head of the
Tokyo office of JCO Co., the private company which operates the
plant. The three workers reported that they saw a flash of blue
light, and then became nauseous and sick.

   The blue light is thought to be a sign of a ``criticality
incident,'' which is the point at which a nuclear chain reaction
occurs, similar to what happens inside a nuclear reactor.

   But a storage facility like the uranium processing plant does
not possess the controls or safeguards that a nuclear reactor
would. The three workers exposed to high levels of radiation were
transferred by helicopter from a local hospital to one specializing
in radiation sickness.

   Two of the workers are in a state of shock and have fever and
diarrhea, as well as highly elevated white blood cell counts,
according to hospital officials.

   Eleven other workers plus five nearby residents are being
treated for lower-level radiation exposure.

   ``We apologize from the bottom of our hearts,'' said Koji
Kitani, president of the operating firm JCO Co., as he bowed deeply
in apology at a news conference.

   Rain falling over the area is raising concern. It can prevent
radioactivity from dispersing in the air, and instead push it back
down toward the ground. Residents are being advised to immediately
wipe off any rain that lands on them.

   Railway service to the Tokaimura area has been suspended. All
schools and universities within a radius of 6 miles of the plant
were ordered closed on Friday.

   The Japanese government has announced the formation of a task
force to investigate the leak. Japanese media are also reporting
that the government is asking for US assistance.

   With few natural energy resources, Japan relies heavily on
nuclear power. It has 51 commercial nuclear power reactors that
provide the country with one-third of all its electricity.

   But public faith in the safety of nuclear power has been waning
as Japan has suffered several serious nuclear accidents. In fact,
the country's worst accident prior to this also took place at the
Tokaimura facility, although in a different building. In that
accident, in March 1997, a fire caused 37 workers to be exposed to
low-level radiation.

   In July, radioactive cooling water leaked from a cracked pipe in
a nuclear reactor 200 miles west of Tokyo. Radiation levels within
the plant briefly reached levels 11,500 times over the safety
limit, but no radiation was leaked into the atmosphere, and no one
was injured.
